metadata.synopsis: Gale's default dialog that triggers whenever you speak to Gale in the game world. Covers a variety of topics that mostly react to Gale-related events that took place.

38.speaker: Gale
38.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

48.speaker: Gale
48.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

76.speaker: Gale
76.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

101.speaker: Gale
101.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

111.speaker: Gale
111.text: A fine job you did back there. Not exactly how I would have approached it, but we all have our quirks when it comes to using magic. Some more than others.
111.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

116.speaker: Gale
116.text: A fine job you did back there. Not exactly how I would have approached it, but we all have our quirks when it comes to using magic. Some more than others.
116.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

122.speaker: Gale
122.text: There's the makings of a fine follower of Mystra within you, give or take a few decades of studying the Weave.
122.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

18.speaker: Gale
18.text: Now, given my magical expertise is of limited use to you, was there something else you wanted to ask me about?
18.context: NodeContext: Hint of sass, but not too stroppy

138.speaker: Gale
138.text: Nothing like a good singeing to teach us the perils of dabbling with magic we don't understand. And the wisdom of stepping aside for those who do.

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: So - assuming you're more willing to take my words to heart from now on - what can I do for you?

162.speaker: Gale
162.text: Sorry, if I'm to engage in banter, I prefer it to be with the leader of our troupe.
162.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

183.speaker: Gale
183.text: Sorry, if I'm to engage in banter, I prefer it to be with the leader of our troupe.
183.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

203.speaker: Gale
203.text: A moment's peace, if you will. I need time to process.
203.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

235.speaker: Gale
235.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

241.speaker: Gale
241.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

248.speaker: Gale
248.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

259.speaker: Player
259.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

82.speaker: Gale
82.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

343.speaker: Narrator
343.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

263.speaker: Gale
263.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

157.speaker: Gale
157.context: NodeContext: He's being given a magical artifact, which he desperately needs. He's grateful.

130.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale absorbs the magic out of the item he's been given (item does not need to be shown distinctly/visible)

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: I don't know what to make of this. Three artefacts is a positive glut of magic, yet my hunger only grows.

249.speaker: Gale
249.text: It hardly has any effect. Mystra have mercy on us all.

43.speaker: Gale
43.text: Listen, I need to speak to you, to all of you. It would be unconscionable of me to remain silent.

155.speaker: Gale
155.text: I might just be about to remedy that.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: There's no need. I trust you, Gale.

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: I appreciate it greatly, but I can no longer keep you in the dark.

298.speaker: Gale
298.text: You have to know who I was. You have to know who I really am.

145.speaker: Gale
145.text: What I am is a walking shadow of the promise I once held.

59.speaker: Gale
59.text: I'm what one might call a wizard prodigy, who from an early age could not only control the Weave, but compose it, much like a musician or a poet.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: This better be good. We wasted a small fortune on you already.

242.speaker: Gale
242.text: And a waste it might have been.

288.speaker: Gale
288.text: Listen, I need to speak to you. It would be unconscionable of me to remain silent.

11.speaker: Gale
11.text: My condition requires a delicate touch. Just one item will suffice to keep it in check.
11.context: NodeContext: Key info for player - clarifying they only need to provide one item to Gale

236.speaker: Player
236.text: Understood. I'll give you what you need.

195.speaker: Gale
195.text: Perhaps I'm not conveying the urgency of the situation. It's incredibly, world-shatteringly important you give me a suitable artefact. Please.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: I can't spare anything at the moment. But you'll get what you need - just give me time.

383.speaker: Player
383.text: You must be patient, Gale. I will help, but I can't do it right now.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: I'm not giving you anything. Not now, not ever.

30.speaker: Gale
30.text: Most unhelpful. In that case, I shall have to seek my own salvation. Elsewhere.
30.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, in a huff - about to leave party

36.speaker: Player
36.text: What will happen to this item should I give it to you?

272.speaker: Gale
272.text: I will consume the magic inside. What was a powerful artefact will be rendered no more than a trinket.

5.speaker: Gale
5.text: But it will save my life - even if only temporarily.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: The items you want are more use to me unconsumed. You can't have anything yet.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: I can't help just now. Bear with me, please.

333.speaker: Gale
333.text: Of course. I would hate for you to think me impatient, or ungrateful. I shall persevere, for now.

177.speaker: Gale
177.text: Of course. I would hate for you to think me impatient, or ungrateful. I shall persevere, for now.

150.text: I see. Let me remind you that this is not something that can be ignored forever. Artefacts are of little use if you don't live to enjoy them.

217.speaker: Gale
217.text: I see. Let me remind you that this is not something that can be ignored forever. Artefacts are of little use if you don't live to enjoy them.

265.speaker: Player
265.text: I'll give you the item you need when I'm ready, and not before.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: I'm sorry. There's nothing I can do just now.

140.speaker: Gale
140.text: Very well. A little longer won't hurt... Actually, it might, but I shall try all the same.

60.speaker: Gale
60.text: Very well. A little longer won't hurt... Actually, it might, but I shall try all the same.

191.text: I sense you don't quite appreciate the urgency of the matter. Dawdling may cost us dearly.

94.speaker: Gale
94.text: I sense you don't quite appreciate the urgency of the matter. Dawdling may cost us dearly.

135.speaker: Player
135.text: I can't do that. You'll simply have to go and find what you need yourself.

380.speaker: Gale
380.text: Well, there was an invitation to leave if I ever heard one. Good luck in your endeavours - you shall certainly need it.

251.speaker: Gale
251.text: You'll have to excuse me a moment. I've got pondering to do.
251.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

261.speaker: Gale
261.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

268.speaker: Gale
268.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

283.speaker: Gale
283.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

287.speaker: Gale
287.text: Best we save any discussions for later, given the circumstances.
287.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

300.speaker: Gale
300.text: Best we save any discussions for later, given the circumstances.
300.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

308.speaker: Gale
308.text: If you'd prefer to rely on beginner's luck than my myriad experiences in studying such magics, who am I to judge?
308.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

310.speaker: Gale
310.text: If you'd prefer to rely on beginner's luck than my myriad experiences in studying such magics, who am I to judge?
310.context: NodeContext: Trying to feel happy for the player - they did something Gale wanted  to do himself, and succeeded at it

314.speaker: Gale
314.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

324.speaker: Gale
324.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

326.speaker: Gale
326.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

348.speaker: Gale
348.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

280.speaker: Player
280.text: I'd still like you to meet me at Mystra's Shrine.
280.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

269.speaker: Gale
269.text: I'll be there tomorrow. As will you, I hope - I'd rather not face this alone.

146.speaker: Player
146.text: I'd like you to meet me at Mystra's shrine. We should hear what she has to say.
146.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

4.speaker: Gale
4.text: Excellent idea. I'll be there bright and early tomorrow.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: The 'Nightsong' seems to grant invulnerability. Could she save you from the orb's detonation?
19.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

86.speaker: Gale
86.text: Still, what harms Ketheric helps us, and to deny him the source of his invulnerability would be a very efficient way of harming him indeed.

317.speaker: Player
317.text: The 'Nightsong' sounded useful. Could it save you from the orb's detonation?
317.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

243.speaker: Gale
243.text: Alas, no. The charm Elminster granted me requires my death as the spark that will light the orb's fuse.

132.speaker: Gale
132.text: Making myself invulnerable, immortal or in any other fashion unkillable would render it useless. And gods only know what it might do to the orb itself...

131.speaker: Gale
131.text: Still, I see no harm in learning what we can about this 'Nightsong'. And, if we manage to find it, the harm will be all Ketheric's. So, well worth indulging our curiosity.

337.speaker: Player
337.text: That was a very specific warning. One based on personal experience?
337.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

139.speaker: Player
139.text: Are you all right, Gale? You look a bit... unwell.
139.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

211.speaker: Player
211.text: You mentioned you know about Lanceboard. Any advice with the puzzle?
211.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

255.speaker: Player
255.text: This closeness of ours has to end. I want Minthara, and only Minthara.
255.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: Right. Well, far be it for me to stand in the way of true love. Or anything else Minthara wants, for that matter.
15.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

104.speaker: Gale
104.text: Consider our nascent spark of romance thoroughly extinguished. The wizard is out of the picture.
104.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

32.speaker: Gale
32.text: I hope you and Minthara are very happy together. Or miserable. Whatever she prefers.
32.context: NodeContext: Flustered, a bit scared of Minthara

143.speaker: Player
143.text: About before... I'm sorry it had to come to a choice between you and Lae'zel.
143.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

126.speaker: Player
126.text: About before... I'm sorry it had to come to a choice between you and Wyll.
126.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

153.speaker: Player
153.text: About before... I'm sorry it had to come to a choice between you and Karlach.
153.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

68.speaker: Player
68.text: About before... I'm sorry it had to come to a choice between you and Astarion.
68.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

8.speaker: Player
8.text: I brought you the Annals of Karsus. Shall we see what's inside?
8.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

344.speaker: Player
344.text: I gave you a strange Netherese tome - the Annals of Karsus. Shall we see what it says?
344.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

31.speaker: Player
31.text: I found the Annals of Karsus. Here - you should read them.
31.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I found a strange Netherese tome - the Annals of Karsus. Here - you might make more sense of it than I.
121.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

105.speaker: Player
105.text: I found a Netherese tome called the Annals of Karsus. Here - you should read it.
105.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

352.speaker: Player
352.text: Tell him of your encounter with his tressym.
352.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

327.speaker: Player
327.text: You and I had the beginnings of something before, I think... but we didn't act, and now it's too late, unfortunately...
327.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

329.speaker: Gale
329.text: Worry not. I carry my regrets wherever I go, and am used to their weight. One more will not break my back.
329.context: NodeContext: heartbroken, but feigning good humour

163.speaker: Player
163.text: I suppose you're already aware, but Astarion and I are finished.
163.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: I suppose you're already aware, but Karlach and I are finished.
87.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

318.speaker: Player
318.text: I suppose you're already aware, but Lae'zel and I are finished.
318.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

213.speaker: Player
213.text: I suppose you're already aware, but Shadowheart and I are finished.
213.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: I suppose you're already aware, but Wyll and I are finished.
78.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

339.speaker: Player
339.text: I wanted to speak about us for a moment.
339.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Gale's no stranger to the uncanny. He might not flinch at the truth - that you're a vampire spawn...
22.context: InternalNodeContext: Avatar Astarion has the option to tell his companion that he's a vampire spawn.

364.speaker: Player
364.text: Elminster said I should talk to you.

3.speaker: Gale
3.text: Ah. Then I expect he's told you at least some of my story? Allow me to give my own side, for a moment.

193.speaker: Player
193.text: Tell me a bit more about yourself.

331.speaker: Player
331.text: I think I have a magical artefact you'll be interested in.

279.speaker: Player
279.text: I think I have a magical artefact you'll be interested in.

282.speaker: Gale
282.text: Your enterprising approach to my problem is most encouraging, but it is a delicate process to keep my condition stable.

118.speaker: Gale
118.text: I do not yet need to consume an item, but keep it close by. It will not be too much longer.

125.speaker: Gale
125.text: That is most gratifying to hear. May I?

220.speaker: Player
220.text: You were going to tell me about your past - who you are.

171.speaker: Player
171.text: Gale... how would you feel about having another person in our relationship?

378.speaker: Gale
378.text: What, like a child? I'm not quite sure I'd consider myself father material, plus our current lifestyle isn't exactly what I'd call settled...

341.speaker: Player
341.text: It's Halsin. He wants to be with me - but he doesn't ask that I sacrifice you. We would... share.

178.speaker: Gale
178.text: Share? You're not a loaf of bread to be divvied up at supper-time! I thought what we had meant something to you.

7.speaker: Gale
7.text: Call me selfish, or old-fashioned, but I cannot agree to that. Either we dedicate ourselves to one another, or this ends here.

230.speaker: Gale
230.text: Very well. Let's... let's not speak of this again. Given my condition, I'm not sure it's wise for me invite undue stress upon myself.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: I'm afraid this is the end for you and I.

55.speaker: Gale
55.text: I see. Thank you - this is most illuminating. I had thought I had the measure of your character, but clearly there is much I have yet to learn.

355.speaker: Gale
355.text: Enjoy your open relationship. Ideally far from my view.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: Not a child, Gale. Another lover. An open arrangement.

359.speaker: Gale
359.text: Apologies. I was foolish enough to convince myself that I was enough for you.

267.speaker: Player
267.text: Was it strange, to see Mystra's likeness again?
267.context: NodeContext: Reflective, thinking back on a passionate former love

0.speaker: Gale
0.text: Strangely, no. Once, a mere glimpse of her face would have been enough to turn my insides over, but not this time.
0.context: NodeContext: Reflective, thinking back on a passionate former love

172.speaker: Gale
172.text: In her likeness, I used to read a thousand stories. She was beauty, wisdom, elegance, power... she contained universes. But now... it is hard to see any redeeming qualities in a lover who condemned you to death.
172.context: NodeContext: Reflective, thinking back on a passionate former love

137.speaker: Gale
137.text: I'd much rather gaze into your eyes than hers. Yours are capable of tenderness, and feeling. No god could ever compare.
137.context: NodeContext: Refocusing on the player, his current and equally passionate lover

106.speaker: Player
106.text: You wanted to speak about that night we spent together?
106.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

365.speaker: Player
365.text: You wanted to speak about that night we spent together?
365.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: About our night together, where you showed me the Outer Planes...
75.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

176.speaker: Gale
176.text: Please, do not not dredge that up. My unhappiness has only just settled to the bottom.

291.speaker: Gale
291.text: Whatever comes next, I must consider with a rational mind, not an emotional one. There are more important things out there than you and I. You made that quite clear.

244.speaker: Player
244.text: About our night together, where you showed me the Outer Planes...
244.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: You wanted to talk about the night we spent together.
37.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: How are you feeling after our conversation under the stars?
58.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

330.speaker: Player
330.text: I'm glad you opened up to me that night under the stars. I wish we had more time together.
330.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

123.speaker: Player
123.text: I'm glad you opened up to me that night under the stars. I wish we had more time together.
123.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

353.speaker: Player
353.text: I'm glad you opened up to me that night under the stars. Do you want to talk about it further?
353.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: I hope I wasn't too blunt during our conversation under the stars.
26.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

91.speaker: Gale
91.text: Please. There is little more to be said on the subject. The best thing you and I can do is march on... towards whatever awaits us.

246.speaker: Gale
246.text: The end may be close. Time to reap what we have sown.

322.speaker: Player
322.text: Did you still want to talk about the night we spent together?
322.context: InternalNodeContext: Did romantic version with Gale, postponed discussion, broke up with him, and then want to resume that state.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: That protocol of yours, why make it so difficult?

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: The instructions were easy enough, weren't they? If slightly elaborate.

271.speaker: Gale
271.text: Like I said: I'm dangerous even in death. I'm merely trying to protect those around me.

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: I find that a healthy amount of theatrics - a voice from the beyond, a magic flute, a friendly if highly combustible magma mephit - tends to make for a more compelling case.

306.speaker: Gale
306.text: If nothing else, I'm sure I piqued your curiosity.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I was wondering, that condition of yours, why does it require magic?

6.speaker: Gale
6.text: Think of it as vampirism. You need blood to sustain yourself, I need magic.

224.speaker: Gale
224.text: It has become my sustenance. Without it... Well, I hardly need to tell you.

328.speaker: Gale
328.text: Think of it as... tribute. The kind a king might pay to a more powerful neighbour to avoid invasion.

189.speaker: Gale
189.text: As long as I pay there will peace. But should I ever stop, along comes a war.

253.speaker: Gale
253.text: I can assure you the battlefield would extend well beyond the borders of my body alone.

81.speaker: Gale
81.text: 'An eruption the size of Waterdeep', I think my exact words were.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: I never realised it was so easy to cast magic.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: Consider telling him about your worship of Lady Shar.

371.speaker: Player
371.text: Do you have much experience being a teacher of magic? I suspect so.

295.speaker: Gale
295.text: I've had a pupil or two, but never for very long. Their ineptitudes tend to... irk me.

345.speaker: Gale
345.text: You do seem to be a precocious talent though. I can always tell when I meet with a keen mind receptive to Mystra.

305.speaker: Gale
305.text: Keep it up and she might just take a personal interest in you one of these days.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: So what did you think about what I pictured when we were connected by the Weave?

168.speaker: Player
168.text: There's something I don't understand. If Mystra abandoned you, how can you still cast magic?

46.speaker: Gale
46.text: The Weave is still here, all around us - inside of us too. As long as the goddess lives, magic is a tangible thing for those who know how to touch.

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: I've studied magic for many years, and in as many ways I am still a more than capable wizard.

377.speaker: Gale
377.text: It's just that I'm no longer able to perform those feats even arch wizards would marvel at.

275.speaker: Gale
275.text: To have one hand on the pulse of divinity.

128.speaker: Gale
128.text: You have to remember that the Weave is a living thing, both the embodiment and the extension of Mystra herself.

141.speaker: Gale
141.text: She can give and she can take away. I'm afraid I'm still very much on her naughty list.

182.speaker: Player
182.text: It was a pity your lesson in the Weave ended so soon - I was enjoying our moment alone. Do you think about us being alone again?

158.speaker: Gale
158.text: You see, I'm not a big believer in fate, but I do believe in serendipity.

24.speaker: Gale
24.text: Life is a tempest of events that sometimes we brace against and sometimes embrace.

114.speaker: Gale
114.text: You're one such event that, one day soon perhaps, I'd like to embrace.

286.speaker: Gale
286.text: I do, as a matter of fact.

238.speaker: Player
238.text: When I said we could be more than friends, you answered 'perhaps'. What does that really mean?

42.speaker: Gale
42.text: If I recall correctly, the Waterdhavian Dictionary of the Common Tongue of Faerûn defines it as an adverb that conveys the meaning of 'it may be that', or 'possibly'.

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: Sorry, sometimes I just can't help being quite insufferable. In seriousness, I'm glad you asked that question.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: Is Mystra always such a demanding goddess?

274.speaker: Gale
274.text: She expects those who seek to use the Weave to do so honestly, and with respect for its potential to destroy, as well as its potential to save.

202.speaker: Gale
202.text: I doubt she's asked many of her followers to blow themselves up. That's a fate she's bequeathed exclusively to me.

340.speaker: Gale
340.text: She wouldn't ask such a thing if it weren't our only means of survival. However much she's annoyed at me.

316.speaker: Player
316.text: How are you feeling? It can't be easy, facing the possibility of death...

250.speaker: Gale
250.text: Oh, you know me - ever the optimist. I'm trying to focus on the positives.

367.speaker: Gale
367.text: The truth is, I was living on borrowed time already. Consuming those items would only have kept the orb sated for so long.

360.speaker: Gale
360.text: If anything, I feel more at peace than I have in months. At least now I know my death will have purpose. It won't be a distant 'bang' in the footnotes of history.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: Why doesn't Elminster take on the Absolute? Or Mystra herself?
124.context: NodeContext: respectful of Elminster. Gale accepting his grim responsibility

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: I've no doubt she has the power to do so, but as for the permission... Ao would not look kindly on her meddling in mortal affairs. Divine intervention has a tendency to make things worse, not better.
72.context: NodeContext: respectful of Elminster. Gale accepting his grim responsibility

215.speaker: Gale
215.text: As for Elminster... He's saved the realms more times than legend can recount. But to take on a god is no easy feat, even for him. My orb is the best chance we have - and only I can wield it.
215.context: NodeContext: respectful of Elminster. Gale accepting his grim responsibility

245.speaker: Player
245.text: I was wondering about that 'mighty lord' you told me about in your story.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: I was wondering about that 'mighty lord' you told me about in your story. Karsus, I assume.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: If you ever feel the Netherese magic overtaking you, what will you do?

312.speaker: Gale
312.text: If it should ever come to that, if I ever know I am no longer able to stop it, I will do anything I can to ensure no one but me pays for my mistakes.

226.speaker: Gale
226.text: I will find the remotest place on the surface of Faerûn, or perhaps far below in the depths of the Underdark.

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: I will await that death alone.

28.speaker: Gale
28.text: I promise I will not betray your trust. You kept me by your side despite the menace that I am.

200.speaker: Gale
200.text: If worst comes to worst, I will be gone long before the curtain falls.

154.speaker: Player
154.text: We've been given a rare gift. An Astral-Touched Tadpole, with the power to grant you a new, partial illithid form...

136.speaker: Gale
136.text: I can only imagine what I could do were I to adopt the biology of a mind flayer...

108.speaker: Gale
108.text: It certainly doesn't seem to have done you any harm. Or rather, you've not yet done me any harm. Still, there are undoubtedly risks to such a transformation.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: Don't be coy, Gale. You want this power. You know you do.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: I offer you the chance at a truly unique power. One that no other could wield as you would, Gale.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: You will wield this power well, and with wisdom. There aren't many I'd trust with this.

311.speaker: Gale
311.text: If this is what the fates have offered to aid our cause, then who am I to refuse? I'll take your tadpole. Let's see what it has to offer.

179.speaker: Gale
179.text: If this is what the fates have offered to aid our cause, then who am I to refuse? I'll take your tadpole. Let's see what it has to offer.

366.text: In spite of my admittedly fierce curiosity, I'll have to decline. My humanity, however frail, is rather important to me for now. I'd rather keep it intact, if it's all the same to you.

358.speaker: Gale
358.text: In spite of my admittedly fierce curiosity, I'll have to decline. My humanity, however frail, is rather important to me for now. I'd rather keep it intact, if it's all the same to you.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: Never mind. Let's talk of something else.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: You've not taken this power for yourself. So I can only wonder, why offer it to me?

144.speaker: Player
144.text: Will Mystra's anger affect your ability to call on the Weave?
144.context: NodeContext: Making fun of himself a bit

304.speaker: Gale
304.text: I think not. She's furious I refused her, of course, but she wouldn't deprive the realms of my abilities at such a critical juncture.

223.speaker: Gale
223.text: Of course, if I succeed in wielding the crown, she'll have no say on the matter. But first, we must find a way to claim it.

199.speaker: Gale
199.text: She has interfered to the extent she is permitted to. What happens next depends on us, and whether we can destroy the Absolute without using the orb.

350.speaker: Player
350.text: Why does Elminster have such faith in you?
350.context: NodeContext: Making fun of himself a bit

148.speaker: Gale
148.text: I've often asked myself the same question, and never really found a satisfactory answer.
148.context: NodeContext: Making fun of himself a bit

254.speaker: Gale
254.text: He clearly sees something in me that I can't. The wisdom and intelligence required to overcome almost insurmountable odds, perhaps. Or the stupidity required to attempt it.
254.context: NodeContext: Making fun of himself a bit

79.speaker: Gale
79.text: I take it as a compliment either way. You don't get to be thirteen centuries old without becoming a sound judge of character. And cheese, apparently.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: Do you regret not using the orb when you had the chance?
35.context: NodeContext: Trying to convince himself a bit here, he knows he 'should' have killed himself

320.speaker: Gale
320.text: I regret many things in my life. Choosing to be here, intact and unexploded, is not one of them.
320.context: NodeContext: Trying to convince himself a bit here, he knows he 'should' have killed himself

57.speaker: Gale
57.text: The orb's power is undiminished. If we do not succeed, I will not hesitate when the time comes.
57.context: NodeContext: Determingation, tinged with sadness - reminding you that this option remains open

273.speaker: Gale
273.text: For now, to have a few more days in your company... no, I wouldn't change a thing.
273.context: NodeContext: Warm, still holding his sadness at the thought he might die at the end of all this

302.speaker: Gale
302.text: Though the orb still seems to offer our best hope of destroying the brain, I retain some hope that another, less costly solution can be found.

225.speaker: Player
225.text: What do you make of having a vampire in our camp?
225.context: NodeContext: Curious, trying to see if an answer springs to mind

112.speaker: Gale
112.text: I know what it is to hunger... and I know what it takes to keep that hunger under control. He's done that so far, despite his condition.

187.speaker: Gale
187.text: So long as he sates his appetite elsewhere, I'm happy to give him the benefit of the doubt.

375.speaker: Gale
375.text: We all have our burdens, one way or the other.

234.speaker: Player
234.text: My memories before the nautiloid are shrouded in darkness.
234.context: NodeContext: Curious, trying to see if an answer springs to mind

221.speaker: Gale
221.text: Memory loss isn't usually a symptom of ceremorphosis. If it is, they've forgotten to write it down in any text I've read on the subject.
221.context: NodeContext: Curious, trying to see if an answer springs to mind

67.speaker: Gale
67.text: Then again, our case isn't exactly usual. Perhaps whatever's causing our tadpoles to remain in stasis has also affected your mind.
67.context: NodeContext: Curious, trying to see if an answer springs to mind

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: If ceremorphosis takes place, all trace of your former self will be subsumed into the mind flayer's hive. So, to still be here, if a mite forgetful? Still a win in my book.
80.context: NodeContext: Cheerfully delivering a terrifying thought

264.speaker: Player
264.text: I have violent thoughts. Depraved thoughts. Ones that refuse to go away...
264.context: NodeContext: Not taking it very seriously

194.speaker: Gale
194.text: We all have those from time to time.
194.context: NodeContext: Not taking it very seriously

296.speaker: Gale
296.text: I once wished a most impure demise on a colleague of mine who bought the last remaining copy of Etheril's Enchiridion of Enchanting Easements. First edition, too.
296.context: NodeContext: Almost tutting/shaking his head. A disappointing memory.

47.speaker: Gale
47.text: As regards to your own morbid little fantasies, I'm sure they're nothing to worry about. So long as they remain fantasies.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: I swear, what happened to Alfira - it wasn't my fault.
109.context: NodeContext: Slightly nervous, but not wanting to hurt or offend you

262.speaker: Gale
262.text: I'm sure that will be of small comfort to her.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: I tried to kill you in my sleep. What if I do it again?
49.context: NodeContext: Slightly nervous, but not wanting to hurt or offend you

52.speaker: Gale
52.text: I can hardly hold you responsible for what you do while unconscious, but still... I'll sleep with one eye open. Better safe than, well, dead.
52.context: NodeContext: Slightly nervous, but not wanting to hurt or offend you

373.speaker: Player
373.text: What did you make of my improved form?

40.speaker: Gale
40.text: Honestly, I didn't know you had it in you. A dark destroyer in our midsts.

56.speaker: Gale
56.text: It's certainly one of the more unsightly shape-shiftings I've seen, but we can't all be blessed with the elegance of an aasimar transforming in the heavens, can we?

119.speaker: Gale
119.text: Beggars can't be choosers. Such a powerful form should serve us well in the chaos to come.

351.speaker: Player
351.text: The destruction we wrought at the Last Light. Did it not give you a thrill of pleasure?

260.speaker: Gale
260.text: Can't say that it did. I'm not entirely sure we made the right decision there, if I'm being honest with you.

247.speaker: Gale
247.text: What's done is done, I suppose. But I'd be loathe to cause such destruction again. Not unless the alternative is far, far worse.

368.speaker: Player
368.text: I know the truth about myself at last. I'm a Bhaalspawn.

252.speaker: Gale
252.text: I know what it is to have a closer connection than most with the gods. But with Bhaal... that's not a bond I'd like to be bound with. You should be careful. Very, very careful.
252.context: NodeContext: Giving hesitant advice - Bhaal sin't a god to be trifled with

93.speaker: Player
93.text: The vile urge within me has been scourged. My heart is pure at last.

228.speaker: Gale
228.text: Nothing like ridding oneself of a god's unwanted influence to lighten the load on your shoulders.

92.speaker: Gale
92.text: I wasn't sure if we'd lose you to that darkness entirely. I'm glad to know you've found your way back to us.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: I need you to remain in the camp for a while, rather than on the road with me.

292.speaker: Gale
292.text: I question the wisdom of that decision, but so be it.

297.speaker: Player
297.text: Actually, never mind. We should stay together.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: Perhaps we'll travel together again later.

170.speaker: Gale
170.text: I'll be here in the meantime, idling away the hours.

315.speaker: Gale
315.text: I'll be in the camp then, idling away the hours.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: Join me, why don't you? There's plenty of adventure to be had.
